content: The President signed H.R. 4899, P.L. 111-212 on July 29, 2010, with $59.2 billion in spending for war costs, disaster assistance, Haiti relief, and benefits for Vietnam veterans. The bill was passed by both the House and Senate, with the House receding from an amended version. The enacted version includes $58.8 billion in new Budget Authority, with rescissions and mandatory savings offsetting previous spending. The House debated H.Con.Res. 301, which required the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Pakistan within 30 days. The resolution was defeated. The Senate disagreed with the House version of the bill, leading to a failed cloture vote on H.R. 4899. The House dropped its support for the bill adding $22.5 billion for various purposes and adopted the Senate version of H.R. 4899, which included $59.2 billion for war funding, Haiti relief, foreign aid, and new benefits for Vietnam veterans. The debate revolved around additional domestic spending proposals. The debate on H.R. 4899 focused on whether additional domestic spending proposals were emergencies that did not require offsets and the likelihood of success of the new war policy in Afghanistan. Representative David Obey introduced the Senate version of the bill, adding funds for FEMA disaster funding, war funding, and other emergencies like teacher job losses and Pell fund shortfalls. He opposed the bill due to concerns about Afghanistan and Pakistan's support for the war. Afghanistan and Pakistan did not support the war, and Congress did not adopt a proposed House amendment for a vote on continuing the policy. Representative Obey believed the process should move forward. Representative Lewis praised the Senate for rejecting nonemergency spending on troops and urged support for the bill. Other members supported DOD's war funding and disability benefits for Vietnam veterans. Representative Skelton supported the bill, while Representative McGovern raised concerns about corruption in the Afghan government and the role of Pakistani intelligence services. The House debated funding for the war in Afghanistan and Pakistan, with concerns raised about funding running out in August. A resolution invoking the War Powers Act to withdraw troops from Pakistan was defeated. The Senate also failed to adopt cloture on the issue.
